Welcome to PTSD Family Coach.

This app is for partners, family members, and other loved ones of individuals who have PTSD.

It will help you learn about PTSD, and provide tools to help you manage daily stresses and get support for you, your family, and your loved one with PTSD.

To get the most out of this app, you should set some things up as soon as possible. You will need to select:

  • Personal contacts that can support you when you get stressed
  • Photos and music from your library that you find pleasant, soothing, relaxing, or inspiring

To select these items now, tap "Personalize App." If you prefer to skip this for now, you can make selections later by tapping "Personalize" on the Home screen.

Content.title: Family Coach
Content.Content:
PTSD Family Coach

PTSD Family Coach is a mobile phone application for family members and loved ones of people with Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD).

This application provides:

  • information about PTSD
  • tools for managing stress associated with having a family member or loved one with PTSD
  • information about professional treatment for people with PTSD

It can be used as a stand-alone education and distress management tool, or to augment face-to-face care with a healthcare professional.

How To Use This App

This app offers resources, information, and on-the-spot coping tools for partners, family members, and others who have a loved one with PTSD.

  • Learn: Information about PTSD, how you may be affected by a loved one's PTSD, how to cope, and how to seek treatment for your loved one
  • Self Assessment: Evaluate your stress level and track your stress over time
  • Get Support: Resources for you and your family, including websites and important phone numbers
  • Manage Stress: Coping tools for a range of problems to help you feel better now, and the option to create and use a safety plan if you feel unsafe

Tap on any button on the Home Screen to see what options are available within that section.

Project Team

  • Julia E. Hoffman, Psy.D.
  • Laura H. Wald, Ph.D.
  • Eric Kuhn, Ph.D.
  • Kelly M. Ramsey
  • Carolyn Greene, Ph.D.
  • Josef I. Ruzek, Ph.D.
  • Kenneth Weingardt, Ph.D.

Additional Contributors

  • Steven L. Sayers, Ph.D.
  • Katherine Iverson, Ph.D.
  • C. Perry Bosmajian, Ph.D.
  • Shirley Glynn, Ph.D.

Selected References

Materials in this app were adapted from the following resources:

  • Cohen, S., Karmarck, T., & Mermelstein, R. (1983). A global measure of perceived stress. Journal of Health and Social Behaviour, 24, 385-396.
  • Foynes, M.M. & Freyd, J.J. (2011). The Impact of Skills Training on Responses to the Disclosure of Mistreatment. Psychology of Violence, 1, 66-77.

Project Partners

PTSD Family Coach was a collaborative effort between the VA's National Center for PTSD and the DoD's National Center for Telehealth and Technology.

The National Center for PTSD, within the Department of Veterans Affairs, aims to help U.S. Veterans and others through research, education, and training on trauma and PTSD.

"Advancing Science and Promoting Understanding of Traumatic Stress"

The National Center for Telehealth and Technology |T2| researches, develops, evaluates, and deploys new and existing technologies for Psychological Health (PH) and Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) across the Department of Defense (DoD). T2 is a component center of the Defense Centers of Excellence for Psychological Health and Traumatic Brain Injury (DCoE).

"Technology to Make People Healthy"

For more information, see http://ptsd.va.gov/.

What Is PTSD?

Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is a mental health condition caused by experiencing traumatic events, such as combat, disasters, terrorism, serious accidents, or physical or sexual assault. PTSD is highly treatable.

It includes 4 types of symptoms:

  1. Re-experiencing or reliving the trauma, such as:
    • Spontaneous, disturbing memories (flashbacks) that can seem real
    • Nightmares
    • Becoming very upset when reminded of the trauma
  2. Persistent avoidance, such as:
    • Avoiding places or people that remind you of the trauma
  3. Negative thoughts and moods, such as:
    • Feeling detached or isolating from others
    • Negative beliefs (e.g., "I'm a monster," "I can't trust anyone," "The world is dangerous")
    • Self-blame for the trauma
    • Persistent negative emotions, including fear, anger, guilt, and shame
    • Inability to have positive emotions such as happiness and love
    • Lack of interest or participation in pleasurable or important activities
  4. Increased arousal and reactivity, such as:
    • Feeling on guard
    • Being irritable or angry
    • Trouble sleeping
    • Startling easily
    • Problems concentrating
    • Being reckless or self-destructive

These symptoms last for a month or more and are bothersome or lead to problems in social or family life, work, and school.

How Common Is PTSD?

  • About 20% of women and 8% of men will develop PTSD after a trauma.
  • Certain types of trauma, such as rape and combat, can cause even higher rates of PTSD.
  • About 7% of the general US population will have PTSD in their lifetime.
  • Women are more than twice as likely to develop PTSD as men.

How Does PTSD Develop?

After a trauma, it's totally normal to be in shock, to have painful memories, and to become upset by reminders. It's also natural that thinking may be negative and exaggerated.

For most, these reactions will lessen over time. For some, these reactions will continue and will be severe enough to disturb everyday life. It's important to recognize that the greater the severity of the trauma (e.g. injury, belief one would die), the greater the likelihood of PTSD.

How Long Does PTSD Last?

PTSD symptoms usually appear shortly after trauma. For most people, these symptoms go away on their own within the first few weeks and months after the trauma. For some, the symptoms can last for many years, especially if left untreated.

PTSD symptoms can stay at a fairly constant level of severity, or individuals can have symptoms that vary over time. PTSD symptoms can worsen during times of stress or when individuals are reminded of the trauma by triggers (e.g., anniversary of trauma). How long PTSD lasts also depends on whether effective treatment is received.

Problems Related to PTSD

Other problems also commonly occur alongside PTSD. These include:

  • depression
  • panic attacks
  • alcohol and substance abuse
  • problems in relationships, work, school, or other important activities
  • physical symptoms (pain, headaches, digestive problems)
  • increased risk of medical problems

Did you know?

  • More than half of men with PTSD have alcohol problems.
  • Nearly half of women with PTSD have depression.

Content.displayName: Does My Loved One Have PTSD?
Content.title: PTSD Basics

Content.Content:
Does My Loved One Have PTSD?

Only a trained mental health professional can determine if your loved one has PTSD. If you think your loved one might have PTSD, see "What Is PTSD?" Check out "Getting Your Loved One Into Treatment" if you believe your loved one is in need of treatment.

PTSD Treatment

The good news is that there are several types of effective treatments for PTSD, including:

Short-term (several months) psychotherapies:

  • Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT) and other cognitive therapies that address negative beliefs related to the trauma
  • Prolonged Exposure (PE) Therapy and other exposure therapies that focus on emotionally processing trauma memories and reminders
  • Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR), which focuses on reducing the disturbances caused by trauma memory allowing for more adaptive coping
  • Stress Inoculation Training (SIT) and other forms of stress management training that teach effective ways to cope with trauma-related symptoms.

Medications:

  • Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors, or SSRIs, such as Prozac
  • Prazosin specifically for trauma-related nightmares

Treatment may include either or both of these approaches.

For more information about treatment, including where to find it, see the Get Support section of this app or the National Center for PTSD website.

Content.displayName: How Can I Support My Loved One?
Content.title: PTSD Basics

Content.Content:
How Can I Support My Loved One?

  • Learn about PTSD to better understand what your loved one is going through.
  • Offer to go to doctor visits with your loved one to provide support, help with transportation and keeping tracking of information.
  • Help your loved one follow his/her mental health treatment plan.
  • Offer to listen. Also try to understand if your loved one doesn't feel like talking.
  • Plan activities together, like having dinner or going to a movie.
  • Do physical activity together, like walking or biking.
  • Encourage and support your loved one to have contact with family and friends, especially others who have served if they are a Veteran. A support system can help him or her cope better.
  • Keep your sense of humor.
  • Take good care of yourself; you can't help others effectively if you are burnt out or exhausted.
  • Choose your battles; criticism tends to make PTSD symptoms worse.

Content.displayName: How Do I Explain His/Her PTSD?
Content.title: PTSD Basics

Content.Content:
How Do I Explain My Loved One's Behavior to Others?

People may ask personal questions about your loved one's absences or mental health. If these situations feel awkward or you're not sure what to say, here are some tips.

  • Ask your loved one how they want their absences or moods explained. It's up to them, and you, what you feel comfortable sayingâ€”including the option to say nothing and change the subject.
  • Remember: PTSD is nothing to be ashamed of. At the same time, you don't owe anyone personal information.
  • Something simple or vague like "She had something else she needed to take care of" or "He wasn't feeling well / up to it / in the mood" will usually be enough to explain an absence.
  • Questions about a loved one's behavior or mental health can be addressed by mentioning that he/she is adjusting to civilian life after deployment.
  • If you prefer to side step a discussion, thank them for their concern and tell them that the topic is personal and private, and/or that your family is managing fine.
  • Remember, in some cases, you might want to share personal information with trusted others to build connections and social support.

Content.displayName: Impact of Loved One's PTSD on You
Content.title: Yourself

Content.Content:
Impact of Your Loved One's PTSD on You

A loved one's reactions to traumatic stress can affect you in different ways.

Loved one has upsetting nightmares and memories

You might experience:

  • Disrupted sleep and dreams, even if you don't know the details of their trauma

Loved one is isolated from others, detached, withdrawn

You might feel:

  • Rejected or abandoned
  • Social isolation / loss of support
  • Depression

Loved one is depressed, numb, or uninterested

You might feel:

  • Rejected or unloved
  • Hopeless when efforts to reconnect fail
  • Loss of confidence in the relationship

You might find yourself:

  • Assuming some of your loved one's responsibilities

Loved one has trouble sleeping

You might feel:

  • Wary and cautious around your fatigued and reactive loved one
  • Loss of confidence in the relationship

You might find yourself:

  • Assuming some of your loved one's responsibilities

Loved one is irritable or angry, or drives aggressively

You might feel:

  • Tense or anxious

You might find yourself:

  • Walking on eggshells around your loved one
  • Hiding bad news from your loved one to "keep the peace"

Loved one is vigilant, sensitive to danger, or startles easily

You might feel:

  • "Contagious" sensitivity and high stress
  • An increased fear of potential threats

You might find yourself:

  • Restricting activities with your loved one
  • Sharing only "good" news with your loved one

Loved one is engaging in substance abuseabusing alcohol or drugs

You might feel:

  • Distant or withdrawn from your loved one
  • Mistrustful, angry, depressed, hopeless, or powerless

You might find yourself:

  • Assuming some of your loved one's responsibilities
  • Keeping secrets to hide your loved one's substance use

Social Isolation

It's not uncommon for individuals with PTSD to isolate themselves. Family members may be afraid of dealing with their loved one's anxious, irritable or possibly embarrassing reactions in public. Family members may also avoid going out because they do not want to upset their loved ones by leaving. However, isolation can lead to loneliness, depression, and anxiety.

Overcoming Isolation

It's okay to maintain your relationships and socialize and let your loved one stay home if he or she wants. People who accept support are able to cope better than those who do not. Here are some suggestions:

Spend time with friends and family. This can be social and fun, like a meal, outing or game. It can also be time to talk more personally.

Join activities and groups. Go to work events, exercise with others, join a book club, or take your child to a playgroup and meet the other parents. Do activities with your church or spiritual/religious community. Join a volunteer organization or a political group. Join a chorus, or a crafting or creative group.

Join a support group if you need support with a personal or health problem, like pain management, heavy drinking, or a group of other military family members who are facing similar situations.

Reach out to a counselor for more support and advice if you are still struggling with isolation.

Sleep Problems

When individuals with PTSD have sleep problems, it can be difficult for family members to sleep well, too, which may develop into poor sleep habits. Follow these helpful tips to get better sleep:

  • Establish regular bedtime and waking times so your body can get in the habit.
  • Only go to bed when you are sleepy.
  • Ensure that your pillow and mattress are comfortable and supportive.
  • Use your bed only for sleeping and intimacy.
  • Do your best not to nap during the day.
  • Try to only spend as much time in bed as you need hours of sleep (e.g. if you need 8 hours of sleep, don't spend more than 8 hours total in bed).
  • Avoid nicotine, caffeine and alcohol in the evenings.
  • Turn off the TV and computer 30-60 minutes before bedtime.
  • Have a light snack if you are hungry before bed — try something low in sugar.
  • Keep your bedroom dark and cool. Use an eyeshade and earplugs to keep things dark and quiet.
  • Develop a relaxing bedtime routine.

When Your Partner Disturbs Your Sleep:

If your partner makes noise in his/her sleep, wakes up upset from nightmares, or has other sleep disruptions due to PTSD, try to:

  • Understand that it isn't his/her fault. This is common after a trauma.
  • Remind yourself he/she isn't doing it to upset or bother you.
  • If it interrupts your sleep too much, consider sleeping separately sometimes.
  • If you choose to sleep separately, make sure you find other ways to connect physically and emotionally.
  • If your partner wakes up, help relax him/her by speaking softly and telling him/her that they are safe at home with you.
  • Ask your partner what you can do to help them sleep better.
  • If it is bothering you a lot or disrupting your sleep a lot, speak to your doctor or a counselor.

Help with Insomnia

Family members are sometimes unable to sleep well because they are depressed or are worried about their loved one. If you find yourself in this situation before bed, try to talk to your partner if they are willing. If can also be helpful to write your worries down then let them go until morning.

If you lie awake in bed awake for more than 15-20 minutes without falling asleep, try the following:

  • Get up and do something boring, like read your refrigerator instruction manual.
  • If you get up, keep the lights low and do not use your computer or watch TV.
  • Get up and have a glass of water, cup of warm milk, or decaffeinated tea.
  • Have a light snack if you are hungry- try something low in sugar.
  • Read something soothing.
  • Listen to relaxing music.
  • When you return to bed, take some slow, deep breaths for about 10 minutes.
  • Calm your thoughts with prayer, meditation, or "counting sheep".

Anger

It's not only people with PTSD who struggle with anger. Family members may also feel angry about the trauma and its effect on their lives. You might feel angry if your loved one can't keep a job or drinks too much, won't socialize with you, or is angry and irritable him/herself much of the time. Some family members feel angry that the trauma happened, and some feel angry that their loved one continues to "dwell" on their trauma and resent that they have added responsibilities.

Dealing with Anger

Individuals with PTSD often struggle with anger and irritability, which can be upsetting to their family members, too. Being angry can make it difficult to think clearly, and it can be hard to have a conversation and feel understood when tempers flare. You and your loved one can get past this anger by understanding that these feelings are no one's fault.

Try these tips:

  • Don't take "moody" or "difficult" behaviors personally.
  • Don't blame yourself for someone else's anger — remember that you are not the cause.
  • If you're heating up, try taking a time out. This can help you both cool down so that you can have a more constructive conversation and solve your problems later. See the Time Out tool in the Manage Stress section of this app for more information.

Drugs and Alcohol

Family members may try to escape from the difficulties of having a loved one with PTSD by using drugs or drinking. Also, some partners abuse alcohol or drugs to keep their loved ones "company" when they are using to avoid trauma-related memories and feelings.

Unfortunately, avoiding problems with drinking or drugs doesn't make them go away, and often makes them worse.

Anxiety and Depression

Trauma survivors often feel "on edge" and become preoccupied with trying to stay safe. When one person in a family is overly concerned about potential dangers, it can make everyone else feel afraid too. Also, actions that help some people with PTSD feel safe, like carrying a gun, can leave others feeling anxious.

Family members can be frightened when a trauma survivor is angry or aggressive, especially if they worry about becoming the target.

There may be changes in family life when a loved one has PTSD or other symptoms after a trauma, including changes in income, time spent together, and levels of closeness. When PTSD lasts for a long time, you may begin to lose hope that your family will ever "get back to normal." This can lead to depression, and feelings of grief and loss.

Health Problems

Family members of individuals with PTSD can also develop health problems.

Bad habits like drinking, smoking, poor diet, and inactivity may worsen as a result of the stress of dealing with a loved one's PTSD. Also, when family members constantly feel anxious, worried, angry, or depressed, they are more likely to develop stomach and digestive problems, headaches, and muscle pain.

Embarrassment or Shame

Family members who believe that having PTSD is a sign of weakness or damage may be embarrassed or ashamed of their loved one. This may be especially true if the person with PTSD has angry outbursts, flashbacks, or other symptoms of PTSD in public.

Embarrassment and shame can lead loved ones to withdraw from others or to keep their problems to themselves. Unfortunately, these strategies can backfire and leave you isolated and unsupported. They also reinforce ideas that PTSD is a sign of weakness or damage, rather than a normal response to abnormal circumstances.

Compassion Fatigue

Supporting a loved one with PTSD can be stressful and at times seem overwhelming — from the demands on your time and energy to the emotional impact. To be there for them, you need to take care of yourself, too.

Compassion fatigue is a state that caregivers and helpers may experience of exhaustion, distress, and preoccupation with the suffering of the people they care for. Some symptoms can be similar to PTSD and include:

  • Thinking and worrying a lot about your loved one, feeling very upset about their experience.
  • Losing sleep or having upsetting dreams or flashbacks connected to your loved one's trauma.
  • Feeling exhausted, weak, or run down much of the time.
  • Trouble falling or staying asleep.
  • Being irritable or angry, even over small things.
  • Feeling hopeless, depressed, trapped, or resentful with your life now.
  • Feeling less compassion and interest in others.

Deal with Compassion Fatigue

  • Take a break and spend some time away. Have fun, or let yourself relax — either alone or with friends or family.
  • Get respite care for your loved one if needed.
  • Prioritize taking care of yourself and renewing your energy with:
    • Enough sleep
    • Regular exercise: even for just 10 minutes a day, for energy and stress reduction
    • Healthy diet
  • Make time for pleasure and fun- do things you enjoy, with people you like. Try the Pleasant Activities and Plan Social Activities tools in the Manage Stress section of this app to start.
  • Take time to be with yourself. Find a quiet place to gather your thoughts and "recharge." Express your feelings in a journal.
  • Manage your workload: Prioritize your tasks, delegate responsibilities to others, and look for ways to simplify, and maintain your basic routines
  • Learn more about PTSD and its effects.
  • Ask for and accept support, both emotional and practical. You can get support from:
    • Family members
    • Friends, coworkers, and neighbors
    • Your loved one's unit
    • Members of your religious or spiritual group
    • Support groups
    • Your chaplain
    • Your counselor
    • Doctors and other health professionals
  • Learn and use relaxation techniques like deep breathing and progressive muscle relaxation (available in the Manage Stress section of this app).
  • Pursue spiritual activities for comfort, meaning, and connection.
  • Take classes that might benefit you (e.g. stress management, anger management, couples communication, parenting).
  • Take care of your physical and mental health. If you feel yourself getting sick or are often sad and hopeless, see your doctor or seek counseling.
  • Avoid self-medicating with alcohol and drugs, or unhealthy coping such as social isolation.

Counseling and Therapy

Counseling or therapy (also called psychotherapy or "talk" therapy) involves meeting with a trained professional who is experienced in helping individuals:

  • Identify and understand emotional and relationship problems
  • Learn about the situations, relationships, thoughts, feelings and behaviors that may be contributing to their problems and distress
  • Learn more effective ways to manage stress and solve their problems

Counseling is available in individual, couple, group, and family formats.

Finding a Counselor

To find a counselor for yourself, you can:

  • Ask a doctor, physician's assistant or nurse for a referral
  • Call your insurance company for referrals
  • Ask friends and family you trust for names
  • If you are the family member of a Service member you can:
    • Visit your installation Family Support Center for resources
    • Visit (or make an appointment with) your command or installation chaplain to start your search
  • If you are a Service member or a Veteran you can:
    • Contact Military OneSource: call 1-800-342-9647 or visit the web site)
    • Contact VA health care system: call 1-877-222-8387 or visit the Returning Service Members web site to ask for a referral

Impact of PTSD on Children

Adjusting to living with a parent with PTSD can be challenging for children and teens, whose parents may be acting in ways they don't understand. While many children adjust well, others may respond in problematic ways, including:

  • Acting like their parent as a way of trying to establish a closer connection. These children might show some of the same symptoms as the parent with PTSD such as being irritable and difficult to be around.
  • Taking on adult roles and responsibilities to "fill in" for the parent with PTSD. This child may act too grown-up for his or her age and get overwhelmed.
  • Exhibiting regressive behavior (e.g., bed wetting, temper tantrums).
  • Personalize the parent with PTSD's behavior as reflecting a problem in them or as something they are responsible for.
  • Needing emotional help for their anxiety (worry, fears) or depression.
  • Showing problems at school and relationship with friends.

Research shows that children of Veterans with PTSD exhibit:

  • More violent behaviors (aggression)
  • More behavior problems (hyperactivity, attention deficits)
  • More school problems
  • More relationship problems
  • Higher risks for depression and anxiety
  • Secondary traumatization — symptoms like their parent's and upset about parent's trauma/PTSD

Children's Responses to PTSD Symptoms

A parent's reactions to traumatic stress can affect children in different ways.

Parent has upsetting nightmares and memories

Children might:

  • Feel confused about what is happening or why it's happening, or scared if they see or hear it
  • Worry about their parent's well-being
  • Worry that their parent cannot properly care for them

Parent avoids going out or is isolated

Children might:

  • Worry that their parent does not care about them, care about spending time with them, or care about being involved in their lives (e.g. school sports games, family outings)
  • Feel neglected, have hurt feelings

Parent is withdrawn, numb, or uninterested

Children might interpret this as the parent not being interested in them or loving them, even though the parent may try to indicate otherwise.

Parent is irritable, angry, or easily frustrated

Children might:

  • Think the parent is hostile or distant, and question their parent's love
  • Walk on eggshells around parent, feel tense or anxious

Parent is vigilant, sensitive to danger, or startles easily

Children might:

  • Develop "contagious" sensitivity and high stress
  • Feel on edge and wary of threats

Content.displayName: Passing PTSD From Parent to Child
Content.title: Children

Content.Content:
Can Children Get PTSD From Their Parents?

While it is not common, it is possible for children to show signs of PTSD because they are upset by their parent's symptoms. This is called "secondary traumatization." It is also possible, though not likely, for trauma symptoms to be passed from parent to child or between generations. Here is how it can happen:

  • When a family teaches a child not to talk about disturbing events, thoughts, or feelings, the child's anxiety gets worse. He may start to worry about causing the parent's symptoms, or create his own ideas about what happened, which can be worse than the reality.
  • Sometimes parents share too many details about the events. Children may start to have their own PTSD symptoms in response to these terrible images.
  • A child may begin to share in her parent's symptoms as a way to connect with the parent.
  • Children may also re-enact or re-do some aspect of the trauma because they see that their parent has difficulty separating the past trauma from the present moment.

Helping Children Cope when PTSD Impacts the Family

  • Explain the reasons for the parent's difficulties. Knowing what is happening, and why, helps children feel safer.
  • Be careful not to share too many details of the event(s) with the child. How much you say depends on your child's age and maturity level.
  • Help them see that PTSD symptoms and trauma reactions are not their fault.
  • Talk about related events and changes together. Listen to their fears and concerns and accept their feelings.
  • Recognize that change is stressful for children just as it is for adults, and be patient.
  • Remember that their feelings toward their parent with PTSD may be mixedâ€”they may feel loving, concerned, protective, and also resentful, anxious, or even angry at times.
  • Help them learn tools to better manage stress. Examples include:
    • Running or exercising to blow off steam
    • Drawing or writing for self-expression
    • Taking deep breaths to relax
  • Give them a journal to keep about these events and their feelings and experiences.
  • Involve them in decisions that affect them when possible.

Parenting Tips: When PTSD Impacts the Family

Here are some tips for parenting children who are adjusting to living with someone with PTSD.

Educate Yourselves

  • Both parents should learn about how PTSD can impact children, and about children's' common responses to having a parent with PTSD.
  • Be aware that children may need extra care, attention, and closeness.

Provide Support

  • Continue to talk together. Both parents should listen to their children's feelings and concerns, and take them seriously.
  • Give kids information at a level they can understand about PTSD and about the experiences and changes of their parent with PTSD to ease the confusion and fear of the unknown.
  • Encourage your loved one with PTSD to talk and listen to kids' thoughts and feelings, and to provide reassurance and support for their questions or concerns.
  • Encourage and organize activities (moving around to blow off steam, drawing and writing to express themselves, etc.) that help kids to express themselves and manage stress.

Be Loving and Have Clear Limits

  • Be loving, patient and attentive, while also holding clear, consistent limits.
  • Understand kids may act out and misbehave at times, and give them some slack for this. Acting out is a normal response to stress, as long as it doesn't become frequent or cause problems.
  • Praise their positive behavior and better ways of coping. Always focus on what you appreciate about them.
  • Encourage your loved one with PTSD to focus on quality and fun time with kids and to delay getting involved in disciplining, especially if they are struggling with moodiness or irritability.

Keep Things Ordinary

  • Maintain basic family routines like dinnertime and bedtime rituals.
  • Make sure children keep attending school and other regular activities.

Include Them

  • Involve kids in family activities. Keep weekends fun with kid-friendly activities.
  • Stay involved in your kids' school and social activities.
  • Ask about their interests and listen without judging or teasing.

Content.displayName: Are My Kids Ok? When to Seek Help
Content.title: Children

Content.Content:
Are My Kids Ok? When to Seek Outside Help

If your child or teenager has trouble adjusting to the stress of living with a parent with PTSD, don't hesitate to contact your doctor or a mental health professional. Here are some signs and symptoms of things to watch out for:

  • Trouble concentrating or engaging in regular classroom assignments and activities
  • Intense emotional responses, such as continued crying or intense sadness or moodiness
  • Depression, or acting withdrawn and uncommunicative
  • Expressing violent or depressed feelings in "dark" drawings or writings
  • Significant weight loss or gain, or lack of attention to personal appearance or hygeine
  • Big changes in social activity or friendships
  • Drug or alcohol abuse

Please seek help immediately if your child intentionally hurts or cuts him- or herself, appears at risk of hurting others, or expresses suicidal thoughts.

Children may benefit from individual counseling. Family therapy supports the parent with PTSD and helps family members learn how to get their own needs met.

Intimate Partner Violence (IPV) and Your Children

Here are some things you can do to help protect your children and keep them safe from intimate partner violence (IPV):

  • Ask your children straight out if they have ever been abused or experienced violence. In 40% to 60% of families where there is IPV, child physical abuse is also present.
  • Develop a safety plan with and for your children:
    • Tell your children about safe places to go in the home when conflicts heat up. Practice escape routes with your children.
    • Teach your children who to call for help in emergencies. Help them to learn important emergency phone numbers by heart. Very clearly explain to them how and when they should call for help.
    • Some children may try to stop a fight or argument in order to protect their parent. They may get hurt as a result. Teach your children not to get in the middle of a fight. Teach them what to do instead when a fight occurs. (They could go to a safe place or call emergency numbers.)
  • Talk, and listen, to your children. Most children want the chance to talk about what they are feeling.
  • Try to be honest about the situation without scaring them. Children want to feel they can believe and trust you.
  • Tell them the abuse is not their fault and that they are not responsible for adult behavior.
  • Remind them that violence is wrong and does not solve problems.
  • Consider getting help for your children. Sometimes parents fear being blamed or worry their children will be taken away if IPV is reported. But often the most loving thing you can do as a parent is to seek support for yourself and your children.

Impact of IPV on Children

You've probably tried your best to keep your children safe and protect them. You may hope that they aren't aware of the abuse that is happening. However, children often report they have heard or seen the abuse even when their parents didn't realize it.

Children are affected by IPV, even if they don't show it right away. Common effects include:

  • Feeling angry, insecure, worried, alone, scared, confused
  • Believing they are to blame for the abuse
  • Having mixed feelings towards the abuser and the non-abusing parent
  • Believing they are responsible for stopping the abuse
  • Having physical complaints like headaches and stomachaches
  • Having bad dreams or nightmares
  • Acting younger than their age (e.g. wet the bed, have tantrums)
  • Having social and learning difficulties at school
  • Acting aggressively
  • Withdrawing from others
  • Wanting to stay home due to fear of what may happen to their parent if they go out.

Content.displayName: Living with a Partner With PTSD
Content.title: Couples

Content.Content:
Living with a Partner With PTSD

Adjusting to living with a partner coping with PTSD can be challenging, especially if it's a situation you weren't anticipating. Here are some tips:

  • Expect things to be different. Take time to understand how your partner has changed, and get to know each other again.
  • Get support. Talk about your feelings with friends, family, and other supports. Talk to a counselor, chaplain, or join a support group.
  • Be patient. Your loved one may be in a lot of distress. Their attitude/outlook may have changed. Go slow as you both adjust to being with each other again.
  • Learn about PTSD. Read, watch videos, listen to podcasts, etc. to learn about what to expect, how to help, and how to take care of yourself. Talk to a counselor, chaplain, or others about PTSD for more support and information.
  • Take time for yourself to do things you enjoy and see people you care about. Remember that you can't effectively be there for others if you're not rested, nourished and taken care of yourself.
  • Be there for them. Let them know that you'll listen if they want to talk (and see How to Listen Well for some tips). Offer affection and support in physical and practical ways — show them that you have their back.
  • Give them room when they need it. Don't grill your loved one about their stressful deployment experiences or how they're affecting them. Give them some breathing room and time to adjust.
  • Encourage them to seek help if needed. Offer to help them get professional support, and support them in doing so.

Becoming Close Again

Partners can feel uneasy and relationships may feel strained if one partner is struggling with PTSD. Here are some tips to help you become closer again as a couple.

  • Emotional numbing is a symptom of PTSD that may make it difficult to express loving feelings. Recognize that your loved one may have difficulty having positive feelings.
  • Understand that PTSD may lead your partner to be more distant or irritable, and you may not feel as close. Recognize it will take time to reconnect and keep your expectations in check.
  • Talk to each other about your feelings, frustrations and anxieties — with respect for the other person's feelings! Talking and listening with compassion, can help you understand each other and bring you closer together.
  • Don't jump to the worst conclusions about your partner. Try not to take mood swings and isolation personally. If you have concerns about fidelity, talk to a confidant, counselor or your chaplain.
  • If you tend to withdraw under stress, make an effort to move toward your loved one instead with small favors, little touches, or a few kind words — then build from there.
  • Avoid saying hurtful things or becoming physically violent with your loved one. Instead, try taking a time out (see the Time Out tool in the Manage Stress section of this app) to calm yourself.
  • Understand that with the stress of PTSD, sexual intimacy may be off the table for the time being. If this is the case, try to focus instead on other ways of being close, like spending fun times together, hugging and kissing, or holding each other.
  • Seek help if needed. Talk to a couples counselor for support for your relationship.

Communication Tips

  • Use statements starting with "I," such as "I think" or "I feel." Starting with "you" or saying "you make/made me feel" can sound accusing.
  • Be clear and to the point.
  • Be positive -- request what you want or need. Blame and negativity won't help resolve things.
  • Put your feelings into words. Your loved one may not know you are sad or frustrated unless you are clear about your feelings.
  • Help your loved one put feelings into words. Ask, "Are you feeling angry? Sad? Worried?"
  • Be a good listener. Don't argue or interrupt. Repeat what you hear to make sure you understand, and ask questions if you need to know more.
  • Ask how you can help.
  • Don't give advice unless you are asked.

Fighting Fair

Conflict will always exist in relationships. Having a loved one with PTSD can intensify these challenges.

  • Think before you speak. Keeping a cool head goes a long way toward resolving problems.
  • When you speak, use statements starting with "I," such as "I think" or "I feel." Using "you" statements can sound accusing.
  • Take "small bites." Focus on one issue at a time.
  • During a confrontation, allow the other person equal time to speak his/her mind.
  • When the other person is talking, listen to what he/she has to say without interrupting. Ask questions to be sure you understand. Repeat back what they said to make sure you're "getting it."
  • Don't hit below the belt with comments about the person's appearance or a sensitive topic. Stick to the issues at hand and focus on the person in front of you.
  • Never argue in bed. Use a neutral room, and affirm your love often.
  • Don't say "I don't love you" or "You don't love me." These verbal weapons can foster resentment and anger.
  • Work as a team to solve problems. You can get a lot more done this way than you can as rivals.
  • Avoid saying "I told you so." Remember that a problem solved is a win for you both.
  • If things are getting too heated, take a time out, but agree to continue the discussion when things cool off.

How to Listen Well

If your loved one chooses to confide in you about what they've been through, here are some suggestions to help them feel comfortable and safe:

Use attentive body language:

  • Sit forward or upright and use gestures, like nodding, that show you're paying attention.
  • Maintain consistent (not constant or darting) eye contact.
  • DON'T make inappropriate facial expressions. (e.g. raising eyebrows when hearing how they coped)
  • DON'T move around or fidget too much.

Talk in ways that encourage them to continue:

  • Show you're listening by saying things like "hmm" and "uh-huh" periodically.
  • Name/say back the emotion being described. (e.g. "Sounds like that was scary for you.")
  • Ask questions if you are confused, and try to ask questions that require more than a one-word answer. (e.g. "What was that like for you?")
  • DON'T change the subject or ask questions that are off-topic.

Show support:

  • Validate (show understanding for) their emotions in a genuine tone.
  • Point out the person's strengths.
  • Focus on their experience rather than your own.
  • Only give advice when it's requested.
  • DON'T reassure them in a way that might minimize their experience. (e.g. "That was so long ago, maybe you should move on.")
  • DON'T make judgments about their responses or choices. The stresses of combat and life threat can be difficult for civilians to imagine fully.

Intimate Partner Violence

Intimate Partner Violence (IPV) occurs when a current or former partner uses behaviors or threats that can make you feel scared, controlled, or intimidated. A relationship in which IPV occurs is known as an abusive relationship.

IPV can happen to anyone, no matter your education, class, race, ethnicity, culture, religion or sexual orientation. It can happen to men or women, but most information we have is about women as victims. About 22-31% of American women report experiencing IPV at some point in their lives.

Intimate Partner Violence can include:

  • Physical violence: hitting, pushing, grabbing, biting, choking, shaking, slapping
  • Sexual violence: attempted or actual sexual contact without your consent
  • Threats of physical or sexual abuse: words, looks or gestures to control or frighten
  • Psychological or emotional abuse: humiliating, putting down, isolating, threatening
  • Stalking: following, harassing, or unwanted contact that makes you feel afraid

Did you know:

  • Rates of IPV committed by Service members and Veterans have been found to be up to three times higher than rates among civilians.
  • Women Service members and Veterans are more likely than non-Veterans to have experienced IPV.

The Impact of IPV

The impact of IPV can reach far beyond the actual or threatened abuse. Experiencing IPV is related to:

  • Higher rates of physical health problems
  • Depressed mood
  • Feelings of worthlessness
  • Anxiety and worry
  • Feeling emotionally numb
  • Posttraumatic stress disorder
  • Problems with alcohol or drugs
  • Suicidal thoughts and behavior
  • Problems with work, e.g. more likely to have periods of no work

IPV: Staying Safe

Whether or not you are in an abusive relationship, safety planning is something you can do now to help improve your safety situation. Some important safety practices are as follows:

  • If you think that you or your children are in danger, leave the situation right away.
  • Note safe places in your home to go if conflicts heat up. Avoid rooms with weapons (e.g. kitchen) or no exits (e.g. closets, bathrooms).
  • Come up with a code word to use as a distress signal to family, children, and friends. Tell them in advance that if you use the code word, they should get help right away.
  • Pack a suitcase with essentials if you need to leave. Make copies of important legal documents (e.g. driver's license, Social Security cards, birth certificates, medical records showing previous injuries) and set some money aside. Hide these items in a place where your partner will not find them.
  • Make a list of people and agencies you can call or go to in case of an emergency. Learn key phone numbers by heart in case you are without your phone.
  • Talk with someone you trust. Even if you don't discuss details, letting one person know the basics and that you may need their support in the future can help.
  • Consider talking to neighbors about calling the police if they hear loud noises or fighting.
  • Consider talking with a supervisor at work for help with safety planning in your workplace.

Use the Safety Plan tool in this app to create or use a personalized safety plan and get more tips.

IPV: Getting Support

People who experience IPV often feel ashamed and don't like to talk about it. This can make it hard to seek help. Also, experiencing IPV can make you feel alone, and if you have been threatened, even indirectly, you might feel afraid to seek help.

Remember:

  • No one deserves to be battered or abused.
  • Although you can't stop your partner's behavior (only he or she can do that), you can find support for yourself and your children.
  • Stay connected to friends and family who support your health and safety.
  • Many professional resources and providers are available and well-trained to help you in a private and respectful manner.

Resources:

  • Call 911
  • National Domestic Violence Hotline
    Call 1-800-799-7233
  • National Sexual Assault Hotline
    Call 1-800-656-4673

Use the Safety Plan tool in this app to create or use a personalized safety plan and get more tips.

Does My Loved One Need Treatment?

It's normal for individuals who experience trauma to have some challenges adjusting afterwards. However, sometimes these challenges are severe, or last more than a few months. Whether or not someone needs help can only be determined by them and a trained healthcare professional. However, if you see any of these signs, symptoms or behaviors in your loved one for an extended period of time, you may want to talk to them about seeking care.

  • Depression — feeling sad, down, or blue most of the time
  • Anxiety — nervousness, tension, being very alert or vigilant to danger most of the time
  • Overly watchful, or startling easily in response to loud or unexpected noises
  • Intrusive thoughts and memories of traumatic experiences that are very upsetting
  • Increased use of alcohol, street drugs, or prescription medications, or using them to cope with problems
  • Easily angered, aggressive/violent behavior
  • Reckless or aggressive driving
  • Sleep disturbances such as insomnia, nightmares
  • Isolating and withdrawing from friends and family
  • Changes in appetite, or gaining/losing a lot of weight without trying
  • Having thoughts about suicide or of hurting, or killing someone else
  • Having trouble working or meeting daily responsibilities
  • Having problems in relationships or trouble taking care of family

Encouraging Your Loved One to Seek Care

If your loved one is struggling, here are some tips for talking to them about seeking professional help:

  • Choose the timing of your conversation carefully.
  • Rehearse what you want to say ahead of time.
  • Tell them you're concerned about how they're doing and suggest that it might be useful to talk to a counselor to get some help with their (angry outbursts, PTSD, sleep problems, heavy drinking, etc).
  • Offer your help and support in finding a counselor.
  • Offer to keep their privacy around counseling if they want that.
  • Come to the conversation prepared with some information about kinds of services available and fees, if you can.
  • Let them know that things like PTSD, depression, and alcohol/substance use problems are common after trauma and are not signs of weakness.
  • Remind them it takes courage to seek care, and that no one can handle everything on their own.
  • Tell them that treatment works. Ask them to just go in for a checkup; they don't have to commit to treatment right now.
  • Realize when to back down. If your loved one becomes angry or defensive when you bring up the topic of treatment, save the discussion for another time, when it's more likely to be productive (e.g., when they seem more open to it).
  • If your loved one says NO, don't give up. Some individuals take longer to agree to go to treatment.
  • If you would like help having this conversation, call Coaching Into Care, a VA service that will help you find the right words to talk to your loved one about seeking help, at 1-888-823-7458.
  • If they are reluctant to talk to you about their problems, or getting help, encourage them to talk to a community leader, a chaplain, or others (e.g., Service members and Veterans) who may be having similar issues.

Content.displayName: If Your Loved One Won't Seek Care
Content.title: Getting Treatment

Content.Content:
If Your Loved One Won't Seek Care

If you are concerned that your loved one is suicidal:

  • Call the National Suicide Prevention Hotline at 1-800-273-8255 (press 1 for Veterans Crisis Line)

If you are concerned that your loved one is homicidal:

  • Get yourself and anyone else to safety and call the police to keep your loved one (and other potential victims) safe as well.

If your loved one is violent:

  • Get yourself and anyone else to safety and call the police to keep your loved one (and other potential victims) safe as well.

In other cases:

  • Your loved one may not want your help, or to receive professional care. If this is the case, give him or her space. You can ask if there are ways he or she would like you to help, or you can simply offer to be available to listen and provide support in the future.
  • If you would like help having this conversation, call Coaching Into Care, a VA service that will help you find the right words to talk to your loved one about seeking help, at 1-888-823-7458.

Answering Common Questions About Counseling/Therapy

Try reminding your loved one:

  • If you don't feel better and it's been months or years since the trauma, talking to a counselor may help so that problems don't become chronic or more severe.
  • What you need to talk about may feel too private or sensitive to share with a friend or family member.
  • Professionals who specialize in working with PTSD can help you learn to manage upsetting feelings and unhelpful behaviors, cope with stress, get along better with others, and pursue your goals.
  • Seeking counseling is a sign of strength, not weakness. You are actively taking charge of what needs to be taken care of and improving your ability to help yourself.

Four Facts: Therapy's Effectiveness

Tell your loved one:

  • Scientific evidence shows that many types of therapy are effective and only take a few months to complete. Likewise, medications have also been shown to be helpful.
  • Although you might feel awkward at first, you can get used to talking to a counselor quickly, and even come to trust them.
  • Counselors are well-trained professionals, many of whom are specialists who have helped large numbers of other Service members and Vets. The first step in disproving your fear is to give them a chance.
  • If you try a few sessions with a counselor and you don't think it's going well, you can talk to them about what you want changed or ask for a different counselor. Counselors are interested in your recovery and will help you get the help you need.

If Your Loved One Feels Embarrassed

Remind your loved one:

  • We are not alone in this world. People are here to help you now, just as you've helped others in the past. Research shows that people who accept help are able to cope better than those who do not.
  • You may think that asking for help means that you're not normal, but it's normal to have problems, and most people experiencing PTSD can continue their usual routines while recovering.
  • If you feel guilty about taking time to get yourself well now — you will be better able to be there for your family and your work once you are feeling better.
  • Counseling is not for weak or broken people. It takes courage, and getting this support shows self-respect, strength and resilience.

What Is Counseling/Therapy?

Counseling or Therapy (also called psychotherapy or "talk" therapy) is a process of talking with a trained professional in order to help people:

  • Identify and understand their emotional and relationship problems
  • Learn about the situations, relationships, thoughts, feelings and behaviors that may be contributing to their problems and distress
  • Find ways to cope with their distress and solve their problems

Counseling is available in individual, couple, group, and family formats.

What Does a Primary Care Physician Do?

A primary care physician (PCP) is a medical doctor (M.D.) with a degree to practice general medicine. He or she can treat common medical problems, and may also be trained to recognize and help with common psychological problems, such as depression and anxiety.

A PCP is a good place to start if you need:

  • Medical attention
  • A prescription to help with depression or sleep problems
  • A referral to a psychologist, social worker, or psychiatrist

You can find a PCP in the:

  • Military and Veterans Administration (VA) health care systems
  • Through people you know
  • Through a referral from a doctor, nurse, or your insurance company

What Does a Social Worker Do?

Social workers have a Masters degree in Social Work, or in some cases a Ph.D., and often work as counselors. They work with individuals, couples, families and groups. There are many social workers in the community and in the military and VA health care systems.

A social worker can help with:

  • Practical challenges like finding employment, housing, and government benefits
  • Counseling for problems like depression, anxiety, PTSD, and substance misuse
  • Counseling family and relationship difficulties

Social workers cannot prescribe medications.

You can find a social worker through:

  • Advice from people you know
  • Referrals from a doctor, nurse, or your insurance company

What Does a Psychologist Do?

Psychologists have a Ph.D. or Psy.D. in psychology or a related field. Psychologists provide assessment and therapy, but only a few are licensed to prescribe medications. They work with individuals, couples, families and groups. Psychologists work in the community and in the military and VA health care systems.

A psychologist is a good place to start if you need:

  • Counseling for problems like depression, anxiety, PTSD, and substance misuse
  • Counseling for problems with family and relationship difficulties
  • Psychological assessment
  • In some cases, a prescription for medication for a mental health concern

Most psychologists cannot prescribe medications.

You can find a psychologist through:

  • Advice from people you know
  • Referrals from a doctor, nurse, or your insurance company

What Does a Psychiatrist Do?

Psychiatrists are medical doctors, or M.D.s, with specialized training in psychiatry. They primarily treat patients with medications that can ease symptoms of depression, anxiety, or PTSD, or help with sleep or other problems associated with mental health problems. Psychiatrists work in the community and throughout military and VA health care systems.

A psychiatrist can help you with:

  • Medications for mental health problems like depression, anxiety, PTSD and severe mental illnesses
  • In some cases, counseling

You can find a psychiatrist through:

  • Advice from people you know
  • Referrals from a doctor, nurse, or your insurance company

What Does a Pastoral Counselor or Chaplain Do?

A pastoral counselor or chaplain is a member of the clergy who:

  • Provides spiritual support and guidance
  • Conducts religious services in the field
  • Offers support in emergency situations

Chaplains help people regardless of their faith and religious beliefs, and offer spiritual counseling and support.

Chaplains are not trained to provide mental health counseling, but they can refer you to a specialist like a psychologist, psychiatrist or social worker.

If you are looking for spiritual guidance, a pastoral counselor or chaplain is a good place to start.

What is Couples Counseling?

If you and your partner are having trouble getting along or feeling close, couples therapy may be helpful.

In this type of counseling, a therapist can help the two of you understand where your difficulties are coming from and to help you learn strategies to cope and communicate more successfully, so that you can build trust and feel closer.

A health care provider, chaplain, or social services organization can help you find a couples therapist.

What is Family Therapy?

If your family is having a lot of trouble communicating or getting along, consider family therapy.

In this type of counseling, a therapist helps you and your family communicate, maintain good relationships, cope with upsetting emotions, and understand and cope with PTSD.

A health care provider, chaplain, or social services organization can help you find a family therapist.

Who Is Eligible For Military and Veterans Affairs (VA) Professional Counseling?

Active duty, National Guard and Reserve members, and their families may receive counseling from Military OneSource (call 1-800-342-9647), Military and Family Life Counselors (MFLCs), chaplains, or at installation (for active duty) and National Guard/Reserve Family Support Centers. Some personnel may also be eligible for services at local Vet Centers.

Veterans may receive counseling through VA health care system (call 1-877-222-8387 and at local Vet Centers.

How Do I Find a Counselor?

To assist your loved one in finding a counselor, you can:

  • Contact Military OneSource (call 1-800-342-9647) or VA health care system (call 1-877-222-8387 to ask for a referral.
  • Ask a doctor, physician's assistant or nurse for a referral.
  • Call your insurance company for referrals.
  • Ask friends and family you trust for names.
  • Visit your installation Family Support Center for resources.
  • Visit (or make an appointment with) your command or installation chaplain to start your search.

How Much Does Counseling Cost?

Try not to worry about how much counseling will cost until you have details. Think of counseling as an investment in health and well-being. For many Veterans and Service members, counseling is free or low cost.

To learn more:

  • Call your insurance company and find out about your benefits.
  • For Veterans, call the VA to determine their benefits at 1-800-827-1000.
  • For Service members, call Military OneSource for more information at 1-800-342-9647.

Will This Require Taking Time Off of Work?

If your loved one needs flexible appointments so they don't miss work, see if you can find a counselor who will work with their schedule. Some VAs offer evening and weekend hours.

Most employers will understand and help Veterans and Service members take care of their health, whether it's physical or emotional. Often, people can work out a flexible schedule with their boss to free up time for their appointment.

Getting To/From Appointments

Some people have problems getting to and from appointments. If this is an issue for your loved one, consider these options:

  • Public transportation
  • Ask for a ride from a friend, family member or neighbor
  • Borrow a vehicle from a friend, family member or neighbor
  • Some counseling centers offer transportation services for Veterans; ask your center if they offer this

Life can be stressful for anyone and if you have someone with PTSD in your family you may be even more stressed than average. In order to be there for your loved one, you have to manage your own stress. Tracking it is the first step.

The self-assessment in this app is called the Perceived Stress Scale or PSS. It has been used for many years and has been scientifically validated. It includes 10 multiple-choice questions about how you have been thinking and feeling for the past month. This assessment cannot give you any kind of a diagnosis but it can give you some information about how stressed you are and if you are getting better or worse over time.

If your stress is getting out of hand or if you think you might need some help, it's important to talk with a medical provider for more information.

  • If angry, highly emotional conflict is the main way your family interacts

Content.name: manage
Content.title: Tools
Content.Content:
PTSD affects trauma survivors and the people around them. Taking care of yourself is important for your own well-being but also so that you can be there for your loved ones.

When you are having a hard time, you can tap on the problem that you are having and you will be given a tool to try. Problems include everything from generally being stressed out to feeling unsafe.

If you like a tool, give it a thumbs up and it will be listed as a favorite and it will show up more often. If you don't like a tool, give it a thumbs down and it won't show up again. You can always reset your preferences in the Personalize section of the app.

If you know what tool you want to use, you can flip to the tools screen in this Manage section. This will let you browse the whole list of tools for the one you want.

Rate your distress on a scale of 0 (no distress at all) to 10 (the worst distress you could imagine).

Distress includes everything negative you are feeling, including anger, sadness, fear, physical pain, and so on, all in one score.

This will help you monitor your distress levels and figure out which tools in this app work best for you.

You can rate your distress level — including stress, anger, physical tension or pain, and more, all rolled into one — on a scale of 0 to 10. This will help you monitor your distress levels and figure out which tools work best for you. You can also use it in your daily life to check in and see how you're doing.

It may seem strange at first, but sometimes we can get caught up in an all-or-nothing way of thinking — either I'm totally uncomfortable or I'm totally fine. The distress score can help you learn to see the shades of gray, and help you see that even when things aren't perfect, they may be improving. It can also help you learn to recognize what triggers distress for you.

Content.Content:
The Change Your Perspective tool provides reminders that can help give all members of the family greater hope and confidence. We all have a constant stream of thoughts running through our minds — this is called self-talk. Negative self-talk, like believing that things are terrible or that the worst is about to happen, can increase stress and affect everyone's mood. These positive self-talk reminders give you something to hold on to; they can help everyone in the family to think more realistically, and may even help them cope more effectively.

Although it can be hard to believe, changing the way you think really can change the way you feel. However, if you are in real danger or there are serious consequences for your current situation, this tool may not be a good option until emotional and physical danger has passed. If anyone in the family is feeling unsafe, don't use this tool to deny the reality of the situation. Make sure the family has a plan to keep everyone safe if that becomes an issue; see I Feel Unsafe in the Manage section of this app.
